column1: Pemalang Regency is a regency (Indonesian: kabupaten) on the north coast of Central Java province in Indonesia. Its capital is the town of Pemalang. The regency is bordered by the Java Sea in the north
column2: in the east by Pekalongan Regency
column3: by Purbalingga Regency in the south
column4: and by Tegal Regency in the west. It covers an area of 1
column8: 353 at the 2010 Census; the latest official estimate (as at January 2014) is 1

column1: === Diponegoro War ===

According to the Dutch in 1820 Pemalang then ruled by a regent named Mas Tumenggung Suralaya. At this time Pemalang has been closely associated with the character Kanjeng Swargi or Kanjeng Pontang. A regent involved in the war Diponegoro. Swargi Kanjeng is also known as Gusti Sepuh
column2: and during the war he managed to flee to the Netherlands Sigeseng or Kendaldoyong. Tomb of Gusti Sepuh can be identified as the tomb of Kanjeng Swargi or Reksodiningrat. In times of year reign between 1823-1825 i.e. during Reksadiningrat Regents. column1: == Geography ==
The northern part of the regency is lowland
column2: while the southern part is mountainous
column3: with the peak of Mount Slamet (on the border with Tegal and Purbalingga)
column4: the highest mountain in Central Java. Kali Comal River is the largest
column5: which empties into the Java Sea (Edge Pemalang).

column1: The regency capital is located at the northwest tip of the regency
column2: directly adjacent to the Tegal regency. Pemalang is on the coastal road between Semarang and Surabaya Jakarta. In addition there is a provincial road that connects Pemalang with Purbalingga. One of the famous tourist attractions is the beach Pemalang thistle.

column1: The regency lies in Central Java province
column2: located on the northern coast of Java. Geographically the district is located between 109° 17'30" - 109° 40'30" E and 6° 52'30" - 7° 20'11" S.

column1: From Semarang (Central Java provincial capital)
column2: this district is approximately 135 km to the west
column3: or if reached by land vehicles takes approximately 3–4 hours. The whole district has an area of 111

column1: The north borders the Java Sea
Eastern border is with Pekalongan Regency
Southern border is with Purbalingga Regency
Bordering on the west side with Tegal regencyThus the whole district has a strategic position
column2: both in terms of trade and government.

column1: The district has a varied topography. The northern part of the district is a coastal area with an altitude ranging from 1 to 5 metres above sea level. The central part is a fertile lowland with an altitude of 6 to 15 metres above sea level; and the southern highlands and mountains are lush with cool air with at an altitude of 16 to 925 metres above sea level. The district region is crossed by two major rivers - the Waluh River and the Comal River. Most of the region is a fertile watershed.

== Industry ==
Just to the south of Pemalang
column2: there is one large sugar mill named Sumberharjo sugar mill. Although not a popular tourist destination
column3: the mill have many historical significance which regularly attract railfans from Britain or Europe: it is the last place where we can see Du Croo & Brauns steam locomotives in working order
column4: it is also the last sugarcane in Central Java who still operates its field lines (as in 2014 harvesting season)
column5: and one of only two sugar mills in Java who regularly deployed their steam locomotives into the field lines (the other being Olean sugar mill in Situbondo

column1: == Special food ==

Nasi Grombyang (Grombyang Rice)One of Pemalang typical foods is Grombyang rice. The name of this food is quite unique. It is called Grombyang rice because the portion of the dressing is more than the rice and its side dishes so that when it is served in a small bowl it sounds grombyang-grombyang or wobbling like going to spill. When serving
column2: the food consists of rice
column3: slices of buffalo meat and soup which is served with buffalo satay in a small bowl.
